content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Risk of Rain is an enjoyable Rogue-Like action focused platformer with a great soundtrack. Although it has slight problems with game life and multiplayer, I suggest buying this game. Now we shall go onto the specifics of the game. Risk of Rain is a Rogue-Like platformer that has 10 classes; each of these classes has 4 different skill sets allowing for a very diverse game experience. There are 11 different areas in the game, each with a few different stage layouts. Not every session the player plays will actually consist of all 11 areas. Most sessions, players will only see 5 stages. Each stage is laid out very well that isn't confusing nor unfair for combat. The combat of the game is very strong. It also can remain diverse because of the different classes. Each class possses a different skill set that can be used for different situation. The Commando, being the starting class, is the most all around class in the game. The Sniper, being an unlocked class, is the most situational class in the whole game being that it is a boss killer.Like FTL and Rogue Legacy, the game can get tiring faster than wanted. I played about 3 hours on the day of purchase because of its solid gameplay. As the week continued, the desire to play the game and the amount of time spent started to dwindle. I found that after the intial high of the game, I really didn't have a huge desire to play the game. That doesn't mean that Risk of Rain is a bad game. The multiplayer can easily increase the life of the gameThis brings up another problem with Risk of Rain. The multiplayer is not very simple to set up. You have to go through and get your IP and open ports up on your computer. The hardcore computer gamer should be capable of doing this with no problem, but that doesn't mean that the process is not annoying. Dying in multiplayer can also make it a very boring game if playing with someone who is much better. There is no way to revive your friends; all you can do is beat the level or die. All they can do is watch and hope you die. To conclude the review, Risk of Rain is an enjoyable Rogue-Like action focused platformer with a great soundtrack. Although it has slight problems with game life and multiplayer, I suggest buying this game. Now we shall go onto the specifics of the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												A very fun randomly generated rogue-like side-scroller. The ten different characters each have a different set of attacks allowing for different play styles, from long range single target damage to melee crowd control. Different items augment your character in a variety of way, from healing with each hit, firing missiles on hitting an enemy or raining meteorites down when you use it. Artifacts also alter the way the game plays once unlocked, allowing for extra challenge. The goal of each level is simple, find the teleporter, activate it, hold out against the spawning enemies and boss/es and get to the next level until the finale. As time goes by the difficulty increases, meaning enemies get tougher and bosses will start spawning randomly, this forces you to balance between collecting items but risk increasing the difficulty or go as fast as you can while losing out on items and not being as powerful. Combat-wise the game is simple but is not easy, careful use and timing of your abilities is key to survivng against the alien hordes.The game has solo play, local co-op or online co-op (The online lacks UPnP and so requires port forwarding). This is a great game, and is better if you can play co-op.

												Risk of Rain is a 2d platform game where you have to survive in a foreign planet with the aid of the item you find scattered across the planet.After you find the teleporter in a stage,there will be a countdown to when the teleporter will be fully activated.Don't worry,you won't be doing nothing during the countdown.Spawn rate of monster will be increased and the boss will spawn as well.After defeating the monster in the stage,you will be teleported to another stage.Before you enter the final stage,you will get to visit previous stages that you complete(loop).Remember time=difficultyPros-Item varies your gameplay-Unique character with Unique skills-Good level of difficulty-interesting stage mechcenics  -Good amount of items-active and passive do their part in ensuring your survivor-multiplayer-Artifacts That greatly affects your gameplayCons-Limited kinds of enemy-Somewhat weak boss design-items are not interesting/unique(items do basic stuff like increase dps/health regen etc)-Final boss is not thrilling instead i find it boring-multiplayer do not work well(connection issue/timeout)You might say that the stage structure generation is not random as a con this is because it is to ensure that the Artifacts are obtainable and accessableOverall,i think this is a great game and you should get it.However boss fights are boring as yo can scum the boss by getting to a place the boss can't access.I Find myself getting into the game and you probably will7.5/10 Great game

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Extremely fun game if you can handle the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t it dishes out at you. Until learning how to play the game properly, I can remember dying countless times on level 1 thinking to myself "I need to stay here until I am stronger" but this is NOT the case. The goal is to move as fast as possible through the levels while at the same time gaining enough money to purchase as many items as you can. The fun of this game is not in compelling storytelling nor in level design or other simular things. The fun comes from replaying the same scenario that murdered you on the previous run... only this time you have a bazooka, 50 drones, gasoline, a ukelele, and a thirst for vengence!

												At first glance, you might think paying 10 or even 7 bucks for this is too much. Well, I thought that as well, but I soon realized I would pay double what I had if I knew it was going to be this fun! First of all, the soundtrack is absolutely amazing! Very exciting, entergetic, atmospheric at times and well..it's just beautiful! It can be a very unforgivng game. The longer you play, the harder it becomes. You can't stay in one area for too long or you will get the shaft of a thousand suns! It challenges you to think fast and survive. I still haven't beat it, but I can't get enough of it!In some ways it reminds me of The Binding of Isaac. The items are interesting and provide strategies. You have a health bar and once you die, you gotta start back from the beginning. BOTH ARE VERY ADDICTIVE!!!I know I'm not the best reviewer yet, but just take my word for it. Buy this game!!!

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Risk of Rain is a lot of things.It's primarily a roguelike-ish sidescroller/platformer with addictive fast paced gameplay. It is also fun. It is also incredibly challenging. It is also somewhat new. It also very, very fun.You have to unlock most items and classes. The class you start with is very balanced, and while it might get repetitive to play it time after time until you start unlocking more stuff, it certainly pays off as you'll find an entertaining and diverse cast of playable characters, each with their own distinct playstyles and roles.Multiplayer is downright amazing. It can be bothersome to decide who gets to keep each item sometimes and much like most co-op games, someone who doesn't carry their own weight could easily cause your doom, but regardless, when you get a well coordinated team, or at least one with a minimal amount of synergy, it becomes the sort of experience that many co-op games strive to achieve.If you dig roguelikes, and/or games to play with your friends, you should totally check this out.

Posted: January 27, 2015
												It's still a tiny bit buggy, but for being developed by one person in their spare time, this game is phenomenal. It's easily worth twice what it's listed for. The music is great, the graphics are sharp and interesting, the gameplay is clean and tight, and it's deeper than the ocean. The game could survive on the strength of the first playable character, but each newly unlocked character adds a whole new dimension to the excellent co-op experience. Be prepared to be frustrated, be prepared to die unfairly, be prepared to make the wrong decision and end your run early, but most of all - be prepared to love this game to death.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												Risk of Rain is an utter joy to play for fans of roguelikes and tough-as-nails action-platformers. It's also a game that reveals itself to you in layers, forcing you to hone your skills with each attempt to navigate the game's six randomly generated levels.Don't be fooled by the charming lo-fi pixel graphics and soundtrack – you will be steamrolled by the game's punishing difficulty your first time out the gate. A little perseverence pays big dividends as you unlock more sci-fi-flavored characters and gear (and learn how to contend with the always-increasing difficulty timer). The inclusion of local and online multiplayer adds to RoR's replayability, making this a must-buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Ah, Risk of Rain. Risk of Rain, Risk of Rain. This game. I don't even know where to start, really. It's an almagam of insanity, part platformer, shooter, bullet hell, whatever-the-hell a rougelike is, and oh so much more. The difficulty curve is absurd, to start. All powerups and upgrades are delivered through pure chance, in such a way that ensures that, while you will always get at least some sort of powerup in every level, the actual item is almost impossible to accurately predict (think Binding of Issac; you can get another friggin' speed boost, you can get an item of little use to your particular class, or you can get something that turns you into what amounts as an invincible hellbeast). However, almost none of them are absolute game winners, and regardless of the Items you get, you'd damn well better know how to use them. The music is absolutely fantastic, the controls are some of the tightest you'd ever encounter, and the varied classes to chose from allow for a massive amount of control over how the hell you're going to survive all those monsters (Hint: You probably won't). It gets harder as time goes on, with the difficulty increasing every 5 minutes. (There's also the base 3 difficulties, easy, medium, and hard. The difficulty still scales with them, but on a different amount for each, so Impossible (about 45 minutes) on easy is still doable, meanwhile Impossible (Still about 45 minutes) on Hard, is, well... Just that.) The catch is that the luck factor requires time to be spent on levels in the first place, so it's a dangerous decision to make. Time Vs. Chance of getting an item. However, despite all these things stacked up against the player, it's quite rare to feel that a death wasn't your fault (Chain of awful item drops aside). I never felt that the game was too hard, rather I felt that I died due to a lack of skill. All in all it's a wonderful game that you should probably buy, because it has multiplayer as well! The downside of the multiplayer is that it doesn't seem to balance with the amount of players, so you can reasonably overwhelm the enemies with your force of multiclass destruction with minimal loss of life (Someone will probably die, however...)

												I really wasn't expecting this amount of fun.  It has an almost perfect balance of skill requirement, a good difficulty curve, and the reward of unlockable content and the feeling of accomplishment when you succeed, with a dash of luck required to spice things up.The artstyle is interesting and each creature and item has it's own entry in a log accessed from the main menu, so if you're not playing the game you can look at some interesting background for it as well as some cool artwork of the enemies/bossies, provided you've picked up their log in-game.There's also enough unlockables to make you want to continue playing, if the gameplay wasn't enough for you, and a number of unique(ish) classes to change your game each time.  Throw in a few buddies and you've got a great co-op adventure.Finally, the music sets the tone perfectly - I'd buy the soundtrack if it becomes available (it may already be, I should go check...)

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												I very much enjoyed Risk of Rain. When I first got the game, with only the Commando as a playable character, I found it harder to enjoy. The difficulty curve from the start put me off, and I didn't know (and still don't) how to play the Commando well, so I put it aside. After a while, however, I came back to it, and started to unlock more and more characters, which is when I realised that the sense of satisfaction as you climb through levels and acquire a veritable armory of items is very rewarding. I feel that, skill aside, some characters are simply more effective than others, and that some of the in-game unlockable achievements are unrealistic (Activating the third teleporter without being hurt once just seems unrealistic for a more casual player), but those are the only negatives I can think of. The art style is perhaps left to preference, but I very much enjoy the simplicity and elegance in well-done pixel art, and find it very appealing.Each character feels unique and plays unique, the simplicity of four skills combined with varying attack and movement speed lending to a completely different playstyle for every character, something that I feel is often lost in current games. The items, some more useful than others, all feel like they have distinct bonuses and different, from the Guardian Hearts to the Jetpacks and the Wicked Rings, and finding a higher-tier item feels rewarding and can immediately change your playstyle.The levels are, perhaps, not that high in variety, but due to the adaptation in playstyle from each character and the multitude of items, they always feel like they play different. However, once all the characters have been unlocked, and all (or most of) the items, repitition kicks in: but this could be said for any game, so I won't count this as a negative.All in all, a very enjoyable time waster, allowing for both quick games and intense playthroughs, the mechanics are rewarding, and utilising only four skills per character, they all feel and play wildly different. Definitely recommended.

It's a blast with friends if you can manage to get the online feature working (still a bit buggy at the time of writing).9/10: get this game!

												Play this game. Seriously. Gorgeous pixel art, awesome soundtrack, very satisfying SFXs. At 10$ it is so worth it. It IS a roguelike, so you will be more at ease if you're familiar with The Binding of Isaac and even more so with Rogue Legacy, but with three difficulty settings it will suit you whatever your skill with these games. Is it hard? Incredibly. Is it fair? Absolutely. Is it rewarding? Immensely. Is it fun? You bet your♥♥♥♥♥it is.All of this already makes it a must-play, but the fact that it has 4 player coop, local or online, is so awesome. If you have 3 friends to play this with, get ready to spend hours screaming at the top of your lungs while you and your friends barely survive a never-ending onslaught of increasingly tough enemies. I know I will.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Risk of Rain is quite the entertaining platformer rogue-like. What I particulary enjoyed, was;-The characters. Even though I cannot play some of them, such as Sniper or Engineer, they were quite fun to unlock.-The simple objectives. Although the game is so simple, of which all you need to do is find the teleporter and eradicate any remaining enemies, you know how to play Commando, itemwise and abilitywise.-The replayability. No matter how many different characters you have unlocked, or how many times you've beaten the game, you always can play it much more than you thought. It isn't something where you have to mod it to be able to play it again (Yes, I'm talking about you, Minecraft.), instead, it teaches you more about the characters you play, and what items are best for  them.-The soundtrack. This, made me so immersed into the game, from what I had seen in TotalBiscuit's review of RoR, really stood out. I turn my volume to 0%, and my Music to 100% in the game options. I just fight on, using every artifact or a few, listening to the soundtrack.-The final fight. This can get annoying if you don't set up a strategy, much like the game Spiral Knights, when you are fighting the Royal Jelly on the 5-2 mission 'The Soverign Slime', you will get destroyed. I set up a tactic, as I had read about Providence after getting destroyed on my fight with him.Overall, everything is well-made.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Well, this review is a bit late, but I'm going to type it up anyway. Risk of Rain is a rogue-like platformer/shooter/arcade-like game. There's no single genre to describe it (in my personal opinion). I shall now continue to focus on different parts of the game.STORYDon't buy this game for the story. The story is almost nonexistant, but still does feel like it has a weight to it at the end of the game. Regardless, you don't want to focus on the story for buying this game.GAMEPLAYThis is where the game shines. You get to choose from several characters (unlocked over time) to defeat aliens and collect loot. Once you feel as if you have collected enough loot and gained enough levels, you can attempt to go on to the next level. I say "attempt" because to get to the next level, you have to fight off a seemingly never-ending horde for 90 seconds until you can leave. Also, this game has a very special mechanic. This game focusses highly on TIME. If you take too long to get to the next level, you might become overwhelmed with higher level enemies. As time passes, the difficulty is upped. This allows for tension and the feel of having to make decisions (do I stay to get all the loot, or should I get out of here and risk dying?).REPLAYABILITYFor someone like me, who plays games a lot and wants a lot of unlockables and such to keep him busy, this game does not disappoint. It definitely isn't easy to get everything either. There are 4 sections of unlockables: Characters, Items, Logs, Artifacts. All characters have a different playstyle and you can always find one that suits you. Although, the characters aren't very well balanced. Certain items are allowed into the pool to be drawn when you open a chest once you complete specific achievements. This makes you want to go back and see if you can get that item that you feel could get you to the end. Logs are little tidbits of info about monsters you've killed through your journeys. It's similar to how Nintendo's "Pikmin" addresses it. It's very similar. However, there isn't a definite chance that a monster will unlock the log. You may have to kill it a lot (it's a random drop). Finally, artifacts aren't something I can talk a whole lot about as I haven't unlocked any, but as I hear it, they change the game dramatically.NOSTALGIA?The feel this game has...is undescribable to be honest with you. It makes me feel like I'm playing an old game (arcade, NES, Genesis, and the like). It is incredibly difficult and not very forgiving. I can't exactly talk about this category a whole lot, but this game (for some odd reason) makes me think of arcades. Not sure if that's a selling point, however.FLAWSYou didn't think I was going to address any flaws? Think not! This game has them! As I stated before, character balancing is just one flaw (not a very major one, however). A majority of this game runs on 2 things. Skill and luck. And a majority of the time, it's rare to get a run past level 3 with a fresh installation (no Steam Cloud. Another flaw). Oh, and there's no saving mid-game.FINAL NOTESOverall, this is a fantastic game, but if you can't deal with the flaws involved the paragraph above, I would stay away from it. But if you can, you are in for one of the best feeling games I've ever played. When you finally complete this, you are going to be overjoyed.9.5/10

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Risk of Rain is an action platformer with roguelike elements. With permanent death as a primary feature, players will have to play their best to get as far as possible. Fight on a mysterious planet with randomly spawning enemies and bosses, either alone or with 3 friends in online co-op. With over 100 items at your disposal, you will find the tools you need to find the teleporter back home. Discover a myriad of randomly chosen stages, from the desolate forest to the frozen tundra. The three main goals for our game are simple: 1. Design a game that is randomly generated every play-through, to keep replayability high and fresh. 2. Time = difficulty. The higher the in-game time gets, the harder the difficulty gets. Keeping a sense of urgency keeps the game exciting! 3. Be enjoyable, regardless of whether you win or lose. No more fussing with complex and non-intuitive gameplay patterns. Players should not blame the game for their loss! ''..joy comes from amassing items, gaining experience and watching your character evolve into a godly killing machine.'' - Joystiq ''This game is immaculate. The enemy design, the sound effects, the powers, the fights, all of it feels wonderful.'' - Eurogamer "..a ridiculously compelling procedurally generated side-scrolling platform survivor-me-do, with multiple characters to play as, single and co-op play, and some of the hardest-hitting deaths I've experienced in such games" - RockPaperShotgunKey FeaturesEngage in local and online multiplayer with friends and other players from around the world! Play and unlock 10 unique characters, from the Commando to the Miner to the Engineer. Fight through hordes of different enemies and bosses, randomly chosen by the game with random abilities and powers.Get lost and discover 10 massive levels with different enemies, shrines, and chests on each one!Recruit the help of a wide variety of drones, from missile drones to healing drones! Unlock the lore of the game through the item and monster logs! Unlock new items and characters through difficult achievements to keep the game fresh with each playthrough. Save your best highscores and stats!

content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												Wow, this is quite the little gem. A very, VERY hard little gem, though!Imagine Contra combined with Binding of Isaac and some Rogue Legacy and you'll have a basic gist of what this game is about.You start the game with just 1 class but as you do special events and just plain find the new classes hidden in the levels you'll unlock more. Each class has 4 unique abilites with different lengths on their cooldowns though most classes have 1 spammable "basic" attack with no cooldown.  Examples of some abilites are the Commando's Suppression Fire that has a 5 sec cooldown but blasts for huge dmg and stuns enemies and then there is the Engineer's Thermal Harpoons that fires 4 heating-seeking missiles for great damage! The classes really are cleverly designed and balanced and they offer a sometimes totally different play style.And then we have the loot.Oh yes, like Binding of Isaac there are many unlocks you can have fun getting plus just tons of items from the get-go. Items are crazy such as a shoulder mounted missile launcher, a cursed mask that turns killed enemies into ghosts that help you, at least 6 different kinds of drones that follow you and auto-attack enemies, magic mushrooms that sprout up and heal you super fast if you stand still for a few seconds, a tesla coil that chain zaps many enemies that get near you... I could go on and on.This game also has multiplayer co-op if thats your thing though you do have to fiddle with port forwarding or Himachi.All in all its a great lil game for only 10 bucks if you love action roguelikes/platformers!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												This is a game you should play. It's an action roguelike, and every playthrough is short, which might turn some people off. However, the mechanics are geared towards this setup. The pacing of the game works nicely, sitting in the nice groove that MOBA style games lie, where games are long enough to be engaging, but short enough to be quickly replayable.Difficulty increases as the time runs up, and metroid-style exploration in the game's levels next to that adds pressure to the time. Should you explore the level with the money you've received by beating the boss and his minions, or hurry to the next level to make sure the game stays at a good difficulty level? Should you stick around and grind, or push for the final boss as fast as you can? These quick decisions make the game engaging, along with the Artifacts system, well-balanced difficulty settings, and co-op play to add to the replay value. The item list is also impressive, with one of the artifacts allowing for the fun of min-maxing your character, and the default setting making most items random, adding to the spontaneity of the game. Items can be unlocked with challenges that test your knowledge of the character's skills, or put you in interesting scenarios. For instance, one of the Commando's (the initial character) challenges involve using his tactical rolls to evade fatal blows, which helps ingrain skill with the character.The only gripe I have with the game is the rate at which new characters are unlocked. Many characters must be unlocked through hidden events on the map, which are difficult to find without guidance. While this approach is fine for Artifacts, which are supposed to be hard to find, some characters are ridiculous, like the Robot Janitor HAND-E's hiding spot-- which is hard to find except by accident.Overall, I would thoroughly reccomend Risk of Rain. Go buy it!

												Easy to play; tough to master.  Risk of Rain is a fantastic neo-retro game with some of the finest gameplay of anything I've seen recently. Tons of unlockables and items, 10 playable characters, and a smashing amount of randomly generated content.The pros:- Lots of unlockables ranging in difficulty- Easy to pick up and play for just a bit.- Plenty of things to kill.- Huge replay valueThe cons:- Slow to start/get started as it has a steep learning curve.- No real tutorial, definitely have to learn as you go (a con because of the above)- Requires a surprising amount of system resources past a certain pointOverall, I'd give this game a yes/yes.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												Risk of Rain is an utter joy to play for fans of roguelikes and tough-as-nails action-platformers. It's also a game that reveals itself to you in layers, forcing you to hone your skills with each attempt to navigate the game's six randomly generated levels.Don't be fooled by the charming lo-fi pixel graphics and soundtrack – you will be steamrolled by the game's punishing difficulty your first time out the gate. A little perseverence pays big dividends as you unlock more sci-fi-flavored characters and gear (and learn how to contend with the always-increasing difficulty timer). The inclusion of local and online multiplayer adds to RoR's replayability, making this a must-buy.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Considerably a very diverse and fun to play Rouglelike.You can play with your friends, which in my opinion automatically tripples the play value. Additionally you can set specific challanges/modifications to a game session to mix it up. Since the maps are procedurally generated and not always in the same order, this game stays surprisingly fresh. Of course, as with any rouguelike, a session or two per day is what I'd recommend. An average session can easily last up to an hour if you are sucessful.A few negative points:The controls are good, but not the best. Jumping can feel awakrd to some people.Connectivity issues do show up more often then I'd like them to appear, and finding a method to make it work can be a bit of a pain.All in all a good game. The pleasing aesthetic and good soundtrack make me love it.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Great, if you like rogue-likes. It's hectic, but not overwhelming. It's a lot simpler than the trailer looks. It'll take a while to play, even one run takes quite a lot of time, on average I spend around half an hour on only the first level. The "It gets harder over time" is genius, as you try to go fast, but at the same time take your time and grind to be ready for the boss at the end of the level. As much as it has the elements of a platformer, It's a minor feature, and it's not a thing you should be really thinking about when you decide to purchase. It's a "Rogue-like platformer", but at it's heart it's a Rogue-like. Oh, one last note, the music. Ohhhhhhhh, the music. Wonderful.7/10, Good, but... I dunno, it just, could be better. Maybe I just haven't tried the multiplayer yet. I'll update this if I get the chancne to try that. All in all, buy it if you feel like it's you cup of tea. Otherwise, find something else.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Risk of Rain touches a sort of sweet-spot for me. It's made with beautiful low-res pixel-art, it's a game of survival and exploration in a hostile environment, it's Sci-Fi and it is incredibly well thought out and written, despite having an intro sequence without any dialogue and characters with hardly any background save for their names and appearances.In Risk of Rain you start out with one character, the Commando, surviving a transport ship crash on a hostile world. Your tast is to find a teleporter, activate it and hold out while it charges, before finally moving on to the next area, and then the next, and the next. I'm sure there is an end to it, but Risk of Rain has a very steep difficulty curve, so I've only managed to get to the 4th level so far, running my play time for that session to 40 minutes or so.The faster you get to the exit, the easier the enemies you encounter, but on the other hand slowly exploring the world will yield more experience and better equipment, so there are at least two key play styles you can pick from: hard and fast or slow and steady.Throughout the game you will unlock items, each of which has a special description text written out for it, explaining where it came from and where it was going before it crashed on the planet. Additionally all of the monsters have written descriptions that will help you understand them, the world you are in as well as your own motivations beyond surviving.All in all, Risk of Rain is a well executed and truly addictive experience that provides short adrenaline-filled bursts of gameplay, that I cannot help but heartily recommend.Playtime: 10+ hours (ongoing)Ratings (1-10)Visual: 9Audio: 8Story: 10Gameplay: 9Overall: 9

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												I very much enjoyed Risk of Rain. When I first got the game, with only the Commando as a playable character, I found it harder to enjoy. The difficulty curve from the start put me off, and I didn't know (and still don't) how to play the Commando well, so I put it aside. After a while, however, I came back to it, and started to unlock more and more characters, which is when I realised that the sense of satisfaction as you climb through levels and acquire a veritable armory of items is very rewarding. I feel that, skill aside, some characters are simply more effective than others, and that some of the in-game unlockable achievements are unrealistic (Activating the third teleporter without being hurt once just seems unrealistic for a more casual player), but those are the only negatives I can think of. The art style is perhaps left to preference, but I very much enjoy the simplicity and elegance in well-done pixel art, and find it very appealing.Each character feels unique and plays unique, the simplicity of four skills combined with varying attack and movement speed lending to a completely different playstyle for every character, something that I feel is often lost in current games. The items, some more useful than others, all feel like they have distinct bonuses and different, from the Guardian Hearts to the Jetpacks and the Wicked Rings, and finding a higher-tier item feels rewarding and can immediately change your playstyle.The levels are, perhaps, not that high in variety, but due to the adaptation in playstyle from each character and the multitude of items, they always feel like they play different. However, once all the characters have been unlocked, and all (or most of) the items, repitition kicks in: but this could be said for any game, so I won't count this as a negative.All in all, a very enjoyable time waster, allowing for both quick games and intense playthroughs, the mechanics are rewarding, and utilising only four skills per character, they all feel and play wildly different. Definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Risk of Rain is a lot of things.It's primarily a roguelike-ish sidescroller/platformer with addictive fast paced gameplay. It is also fun. It is also incredibly challenging. It is also somewhat new. It also very, very fun.You have to unlock most items and classes. The class you start with is very balanced, and while it might get repetitive to play it time after time until you start unlocking more stuff, it certainly pays off as you'll find an entertaining and diverse cast of playable characters, each with their own distinct playstyles and roles.Multiplayer is downright amazing. It can be bothersome to decide who gets to keep each item sometimes and much like most co-op games, someone who doesn't carry their own weight could easily cause your doom, but regardless, when you get a well coordinated team, or at least one with a minimal amount of synergy, it becomes the sort of experience that many co-op games strive to achieve.If you dig roguelikes, and/or games to play with your friends, you should totally check this out.

The plot is you and some other people are space mailmen, trying to deliver♥♥♥♥♥♥when your ship starts exploding and crash lands on a planet, and then you have to get back to it before the space monsters surely eat your flesh. The game has three main difficulties, ranging from cup of water to Atlantic Ocean, and has a difficulty timer in game that starts at 2ez, and then just laughs at you for the highest one for some reason.There are 9 other persons who you can play as if you do some stuff, with my favorite being Handy, the robot janitor (I like him because he has a hammer). There's also these weird black rocks that make the game play all weirdly, so use them at your own risk (HEHEH, GEDDIT!?).the gameplay consists of running around trying to not get killed. When you kill the monsters, they drop money and glowy balls, which make your life numbers bigger. To survive however, you need to use the money to lockpick boxes and buy stuff from vending machines. you can play this by yourself, or with other people sitting next you (player cap 4) or with people from the internets (up to 10 with settings adjustments! WOW!).all in all, I give this hard fun game 2 potatoes out of 3 apples.Edit: Scorpion from Mortal Kombat and the Swedish Chef are now charaters due to an update. +1/2 Potato for this.

												It's still a tiny bit buggy, but for being developed by one person in their spare time, this game is phenomenal. It's easily worth twice what it's listed for. The music is great, the graphics are sharp and interesting, the gameplay is clean and tight, and it's deeper than the ocean. 												Extremely fun game if you can handle the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t it dishes out at you. Until learning how to play the game properly, I can remember dying countless times on level 1 thinking to myself "I need to stay here until I am stronger" but this is NOT the case. The goal is to move as fast as possible through the levels while at the same time gaining enough money to purchase as many items as you can. The fun of this game is not in compelling storytelling nor in level design or other simular things. The fun comes from replaying the same scenario that murdered you on the previous run... only this time you have a bazooka, 50 drones, gasoline, a ukelele, and a thirst for vengence!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Harkening back to the day of the 8 and 16-bit platformer, Risk of Rain is deliberately inscrutable roguelike that relishes in its masochistic difficulty curve. Skipping any kind of pretence of a tutorial or any of the modern hand-holding gamers have come to expect, your little spaceman is dropped into a random, semi-procedurally generated map with little more than the vague instructions to "Find the Teleporter" to go on. Vicious monsters begin to spawn almost immediately and it doesn't take long to realize how hopelessly outmatched your little guy is, and it only gets worse from there.The central conceit of Risk of Rain, and what makes it stand out from the pack of other recently released roguelikes, is the timer. A large clock in the top right of the screen mercilessly ticks upwards with every second. The longer you take, the more frequently the monsters spawn, and the stronger they grow. Every five minutes, a bell marks the passing into a higher level of difficulty, starting at "Very Easy" and eventually tipping into the realm of "impossible" and "HAHAHAHAHA." If you haven't been efficient at collecting upgrades and items, you may soon find yourself surrounded on all sides by monsters you don't have a prayer of defeating. The mission quickly turns from "how far can I get?" to "how long can I survive!?"There is an incredible sense of urgency packed into every second of RoR because of that timer. Every choice and action becomes crucial. What way to you explore after spawning? Should you stay in this area and try to clear out enough monsters to earn enough gold to open another chest, or just book it while you can? While you only take miniscule fall damage, you'll be cursing yourself each time a missed jump forces you to reclimb a ladder, burning precious seconds.As you might be familiar from games like The Binding of Isaac, RoR features a plethora of items to be found. Most of these apply some kind of passive bonus to the character like a better chance for critical hits, a bonus to regenerating health, or a small demon in a jar that might cause enemies to explode when you kill them, you know, standard stuff. Others occupy the fifth slot in your inventory to be activated at will, usually with a tremendous cool down period before you can use it again. These are your typical screen-clearing bombs and the like, as well as more esoteric (and deceptively powerful) options like a Repair Kit that will instantly fix up any drones on the screen.And much like Isaac, part of the fun of the game is watching the strange transformation these items will wreak upon your tiny spaceman. You start as a small blip of pixels, a little speck that seems hopelessly outmatched by the towering wildlife and monstrous aliens. But all of that can change with a few lucky item drops. Wreathed in barbed wire, encircled by a fleet of drones, randomly spewing missiles, summoning poltergeists, and leaving a trail of fire at your boots, you may not even recognize your little explorer by the time you reach the final stage.There are additional character classes to unlock. While you start with only the standard Commando in his adorable bubble-dome, it doesn't take long to expand the selection.Each character naturally promotes a unique style of play with their skills. The Mercenary and Miner feature agile fast moving attacks that double as dodging manoeuvres, encouraging you to keep it hopping. The mechanical HAN-D robot on the other hand has a suite of moves designed to keep him in the thick of battle. An Overclock boost increases his speed and power and can be extended by pounding multiple enemies. His brawling prowess is complemented by an array of seeker drones that can autonomously fly off and leech back health from the enemy while he fights, and so on. Learning how to best utilize each character's tools and abilities is essential if you hope to weather the storm.Multiplayer gives the individual characters a little more room to breathe and express themselves. Some of the more idiosyncratic classes that I thought were a bit lacklustre in single player came into their own with a team. I was worried that adding more players to the recipe would spoil the difficulty of the game. This is definitely not the case. While the extra firepower and the ability to split up and search for the exit certainly makes the early stages easier, having to share the loot and gold among 2-4 people means none of you will become the fearsome blackhole of alien destruction you might be used when hogging every trinket for yourself. By the final stages you'll need to work together as best you can to manage the laughably unfair hordes of nearly invulnerable monsters.While playing with random strangers results in the typical mad scramble of greed you might be used to in something like Borderlands – where every player jumps on every item they can in a micro-demonstration of the Tragedy of the Commons – playing with a coordinated group raises the game to the next level. When you can actually coordinate who gets what items based on what they need or what would be most useful for a particular cast member, you can cultivate a truly spectacular team. Multiplayer goes from being a fun diversion, to feeling like it's the way the game is MEANT to be played.Which is why it's such a shame that it is absolutely broken.Connecting to an online game in Risk of Rain gave me some wonderful flashbacks of the late-90's. Eschewing any kind of server browser or quick-game connection UI, Risk of Rain expects you to manually input the IP and port number of your host. I haven't texted somebody an IP address in nearly a decade, and while the nostalgia trip was nice, it is a decidedly horrible way to run a multiplayer game.It is an unbelievable shame that RoR's multiplayer is hamstrung in such a fundamental way. When I was able to find a match and everything worked, it was some of the best co-op I've played this year. It taps directly into the same impulses that made games like L4D and Gears of Wars Horde mode abiding favourites with my friends for years. Sadly, I don't think I'll be able to convince many people that putting up with all the frustration of getting a match together is worth it for RoR. I know Hopoo Games is a small group, but this was a real missed opportunity that could have taken their game from a being a fun little title to something great.Risk of Rain is a sad game. It deals in desperation, in hopelessness. Rendered in a gorgeous faux-retro pixel-art style, everything in RoR dwarfs the player. The music, brilliantly composed by Chris Christodoulou, is tense, haunting, and worth the price of admission on its own.  While RoR is intentionally light on story, the background of the game is slowly filled in through the shipping details of the items you scavenge throughout the game and a journal detailing the monsters and wildlife you encounter. Many of these little descriptions were surprisingly wistful or tragic, and by the time you've collected the last monster log, you'll probably start to feel like maybe you were the jerk in this situation.That feeling helps carry the game. Risk of Rain isn't as smooth as something like Isaac or Spelunky. There's more technical jank, items spawning in unreachable areas, containers floating off the ground, and the gameplay isn't as balanced or fair. Where part of the skill of Isaac or Spelunky is being able to roll with the punches and succeed despite bad luck, there were definitely times in RoR where I felt failure was out of my control. But flaws notwithstanding, I kept comming back. That sad wistful tone and the wonderfully balanced characters just dug into the right spot of my brain.Risk of Rain might not be the most polished roguelike to hit the market in the last few years, but it has a charm all to its own, and I think that is a fact to celebrate.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I would recommend to anyone whos likes a challenge and good things. Insanely fun and addicting. The soundtrack of this game is submersive and ominous, but the game gets really intense listening to your own music. Sound effects are retro but not annoying, you can almost feel the explosions hitting your enemies and the sounds of bullets hitting their flesh.I have never enjoyed the idea of perma-death but this game has opened up that genre to me, it does a great job of making you feel like ever playable charcter is different, and the speed at which the difficulty, as well as your own strength, on each playthrough provides for excellent fast-action that is really addicting. And on top of everything its online an local multiplayer!The atmosphere and small shreds of story we get from this game are excellent builing blocks for a game that question the human vs. nature relationship, this is built from assumptions incredibly sparce dialogue, and the tormented thoughts of a lone survivor adrift a hostile planet. While these intriguing elements of story and atmosphere are present, they are not so "in-your-face," rather, appearing in monster and item descriptions, these small attention to detail is immersive, interesting and not at all distracting of the core game. A perfect balance of incredibly strong replay value, and a good incentive to keep playing to unlock this worlds story, which we end up caring a lot about.The graffics are very charming and pleasing to the eye. No matter what of the 10 characters you play, your are always a small  pile of about 30 pixels. Not to say that they were lazy at all, no. Rather, the simplicty and smallness of your charcter is great to look at and really makes your feel small in a world of things trying to kill you. The monsters are the same way, though they are larger than you(some very much so), they feel like true inhabitants of the world youve landed in. Bosses feel and look powerful and their deaths are satisfying. Graphically the world around you looks amazing, like the remnants of an ancient alien civilization. They really put you in concern with your characters need to survive.Overall, I give this game a 9/10. The reason not a perfect score is the only could use some tweaking. The difficulty, graphics, upgrades, items, collectables and secrets keep me coming back for more everytime I sit down to my computer. Never, have I put so many hours so quickly into a game that was inly $10. It was worth every cent twofold

												Extremely fun game if you can handle the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t it dishes out at you. Until learning how to play the game properly, I can remember dying countless times on level 1 thinking to myself "I need to stay here until I am stronger" but this is NOT the case. The goal is to move as fast as possible through the levels while at the same time gaining enough money to purchase as many items as you can. The fun of this game is not in compelling storytelling nor in level design or other simular things. The fun comes from replaying the same scenario that murdered you on the previous run... only this time you have a bazooka, 50 drones, gasoline, a ukelele, and a thirst for vengence!

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												Risk of Rain is a 2d platform game where you have to survive in a foreign planet with the aid of the item you find scattered across the planet.After you find the teleporter in a stage,there will be a countdown to when the teleporter will be fully activated.Don't worry,you won't be doing nothing during the countdown.Spawn rate of monster will be increased and the boss will spawn as well.After defeating the monster in the stage,you will be teleported to another stage.Before you enter the final stage,you will get to visit previous stages that you complete(loop).Remember time=difficultyPros-Item varies your gameplay-Unique character with Unique skills-Good level of difficulty-interesting stage mechcenics  -Good amount of items-active and passive do their part in ensuring your survivor-multiplayer-Artifacts That greatly affects your gameplayCons-Limited kinds of enemy-Somewhat weak boss design-items are not interesting/unique(items do basic stuff like increase dps/health regen etc)-Final boss is not thrilling instead i find it boring-multiplayer do not work well(connection issue/timeout)You might say that the stage structure generation is not random as a con this is because it is to ensure that the Artifacts are obtainable and accessableOverall,i think this is a great game and you should get it.However boss fights are boring as yo can scum the boss by getting to a place the boss can't access.I Find myself getting into the game and you probably will7.5/10 Great game

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Easily one of the most entertaining games I have played. I'm not much for the Roguelike/Roguelite series and games which are similar, however I easily spent Eight hours playing with friends, repeatedly trying over and over. I took a break around 12AM EST and found myself playing it again around 2AM until around 6AM. This is a very easy game to lose track of time in, however the difficulty continually spikes whilst playing, which.. Is actually quite fun to work around.From my gameplay experience with this game, it has promoted teamwork with item combinations between my friends and I, and I have just enjoyed every moment of it.Pros: - Easy to understand item system.- A multitude of classes and characters to choose from, to figure out your own personal playstyle.- Easy to set-up online multiplayer (Currently only usable in a Beta release).- One of the most amazing soundtracks I have heard in gaming. After Eight hours, I still want to hear more.- Up to Six player Cooperative.- Continually scaling difficulty, which promotes teamwork and makes player develop new strategies.- Item Collection, and Monster Journals. Each menu option tells you more about the items you use, and the monsters you fight.- Intuitive Combat System unlike other Roguelike/Roguelite games.- Combat Focused instead of Platforming Focused unlike most other Roguelikes/RoguelitesCons:- Port Forwarding is required for this game, and some ISP's may block the native Port this game uses. (Try using 7777).- Game Crashes are somewhat present, and if such happens whilst gaming, your data is lost.- Lag prevalent regardless of Ping of players joining a server.Regardless of the Cons, I definitely would recommend this game for you. I can easily see myself playing this game for upwards of Fifty hours. The game is even on sale currently (4/5/2015) for 2.49.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Ive actually played this game for a decent ammount of hours to the point i can say that it is actually an amazing game. Personally my love for gaming was slowly dying, as all gamess seemed to be clones of another and there wasnt really anything new and orignal out there. Untill i came across this game in a humble bundle sometime earlier in the year at first i didnt feel like giving it a go as the way it looks simple but im so glad i did!  Risk of Rain a brillinat rouge-like Side Scrolling Platformer.  it can be as indepth as you want it to. fo example it can be a neverending loop, where you figure out that youve done a 7 hour sitting after dying. But you can also beat the game in an hour if you wanted to. The items are crazy, the game it's self is beautiful i love the art style of everything and the music is truly captivating. I find myself getting lost in the game with the music playing. With trhe ability to play with up to 7 players online and coop it really is a great game to bash with mates, Also the actual story behind the game is like i said orignal and you will find yourself re-playing to complete challenges unlocking artifacts, characters, little hidden levels and easter eggs that devs put in for a laugh. it really is one of my faveorate game i could talk about it for hours but i wont... i do STRONGLY recommend this game even if you die within the first 5 mins you'll find yourself going back for more as i do. :)

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												RoR is a platform-based rougelite where you are marooned on a hostile alien world. Collecting items to mutate your body and enhance your abilities are key to surviving the never-ending horde of incoming alien hostiles. Time is of the essence, as the horde becomes more and more aggressive as time passes.Immediately the context is given for the game: you are alone, your goal is to survive. Depending on how you play you can be aggressive or passive in how to address the game's starting stages, but more often than not you will have to resort to running away and picking off targets before you acquire the experience and upgrades you need. Before too long you'll be strong enough to decimate colossal threats with ease -- at the aptly-named difficulty "HAHAHAHAHAHA."Now to me, this was where there was a divergence. The startup always felt sluggish to me; kiting enemies for 20-ish minutes before becoming powerful enough to take them head on didn't feel like it was worth my time invested into it. Some may find this fun, I didn't personally. Once I'd get over that hump, the game's pacing and goal changed from survival into a killing spree. This is something that the game is self-aware of with the higher difficulty levels being "I SEE YOU", "I'M COMING FOR YOU", and "HAHAHAHAHAHA" as well as the endings for each character making mention on how they have lost their humanity/sanity during their spree.Overall it's a challenging game to get into due to its slow and downright-disadvantaged start. However that nuance is exactly what was intended to give the player that feeling of being overwhelmed, and it exaggerates just how powerful you become when you reach lategame when you contrast it to how weak you started out.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Risk of rain is a fiendishly difficult 2d shooter with roguelike inspirations. The game starts out fairly simple, you're on an alien planet, and need to find a teleporter. The first stage of the game is not too rough, however, as time progresses, regardless of your progress, enemies begin to ramp up in number and strength. This creates a dilemna, do you throughly search a level for items and monsters to kill for experience? Or do you rush the teleporter, fight the boss, and move on quickly? It's these decisions along with many fun characters to experiment playing with that make Risk of Rain shine. If you're a fan of 2D shooters, or roguelikes and don't mind dying many times over in many situations, definitely make time for this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Risk of rain is fantastic! The game has a very simple yet detailed pixel art style, and interesting monster, weapon, and character designs, each masterfully animated.The music seems to be inspired by retro game beats, yet feels fresh, and oscillates from being adreniline pumping, to calm and relaxing, it's a good, fun, varied sountrack. The simple yet deep gameplay, offers various characters to unlock, each offering very unique movesets that all have been perfectly balanced, so one should be able to find one character that fits their playstyle. While the game is hard, it never feels so due to monsters having an unfair advantage, however several artifacts can also be unlocked to alter gameplay so it either ends up easier, or more difficult. Additionally three difficulty levels can be selected, so you can cater the challenge to your own tastes.The gist of the game is to fight off a neverending wave of enemies, that become progressively more difficult the longer the game is in play, over the course of 6 levels. Each level is completed by first finding a teleporter, then fighting off against a boss, and surviving a time limit wherein serveral enemies will spawn to attack the player, after successfully doing so the player will be transported to the next level.A lot of work went into the design of the game, from the easy to navigate menu's, to the environments available, and amount of enemies you can come across, to the games ostensibly simple story that reveals more depth as you dig into the lore. Along with the many secrets, hidden areas, and unlockables to discover.Multiplayer is a blast, but unfortunately very difficult to set up with others...Risk of rain is fun on all levels, and an excellent addition to the indie genre, that should keep one entertained for hours!Score: 4.5/5 -0.5 due to the difficulty in setting up a multiplayer game.Sincerely,- Celx RequinWebsite: www.cancer-cinema.comTwitter: www.twitter.com/cancercinemaSteam Game Page:

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Ok, so this is going to be a verly decent length review of Risk of Rain, I have about 60 hours in it. and I have beat the game countless times. So, lets begin. As a I will be writing "RoR" as a  anagram for Risk of Rain.Risk of Rain is a sidescrolling 2-D platformer with co-op the sub genre of rogue likes, This means that every playthrough while can seem similer they will be 90% of the time different, also rogue likes are know for their brutal difficuitly RoR is no exeption to this rule though this game has a unquie mechanic there is a timer in the top  right coner as the timer goes up the game gets harder tougher enemies spawn this creates a great risk and reward feeling "Do I stay to get better items/level up or do I leave now with weaker enemies for the next level". With a amazing soundtrack that I can only describe as electronic orchestra and a 8-bit grapics style  that is pretty to look at. Like I said before the game by all means is a platformer though it as a emphasis on combat. The game has eleven playable characters most of which you unlock by a varity of ways, each character has a unique playstyle from the others.  as a example the acrid is a creature that uses acid to attack by either leaving it on the ground or shooting it at enemies  to do a damage over time effects.  Like mention before the game is quite hard on the default difficulty, while fighting your way on a  planet you crash landed on you find items and and dodging and kill the inhabitants of said planet. While you're in any said level you collect gold to buy items at shops that give you effects like for example, the Guardian's Heart it gives a shield that recharges after not taking damage over a period of time, the ukulele which gives a chance to do Area of effect electric damage on your hits. As you move along the 2d map either if its climbing upwards or to just going left to right you need to find the teleporter to move onto the next level, once the teleporter is activated a boss spawns with a timer, the timer counts down till you can teleport to the next level though you can only teleport once the boss is dead, once dead it drops a item, Once time timer hits zero and teleport but it also stops enemies from spawning on that level so you can quickly go buy something and head back if you choose no worrys about dying. The game has 6 levels of said 6 level  there are 11 map themes though the maps are partly randomly generated. Once you beat the fifth level you get a choose, go to the final level or go back to the starting level (though harder bosses and enemies spawn now to keep it intersting) and keep grinding items.  The game has amazing replayability with over 100 items! and being quite challenging this combinded with having co-op as a option in the game just results in a blast! Plus the game is quite cheap with it being eleven dollers flat. It also does a great job of saying "Game maker's engine can make good stuff as well guys!"I love this game, and enjoyed the time spent with it so much.  The game as amazing soundtrack solid gameplay that is satisflying/fun and a ton of replayabiltiy solo or multiplayer you're sure to have a blast. The game earns at least a 9/10.  (Would link steam page but we're here so...) To buy the sound track go here: https://chrischristodoulou.bandcamp.com/album/risk-of-rain (favorite track: Coalescence) Thanks for reading! Hope you could find it useful if you would like to send me any critism by all means post it on my steam profile/here thanks!  If you want to watch me play games I stream over at www.twitch.tv/mrfirestorm

Posted: March 1
												Definately my favorite rogue lite to date... At first you will die a lot, but after some time you'll get the hang of it, unlock further items and characters to play with. Characters are quite varied with many different special attacks and powers, some will definately fit your type of playstyle. This is were the game gets fun. You shoot / hack / crush / fry your way through endless counts of enemies, collecting items, growing stronger and stronger, which is even more enjoyable, when playing with some friends... Great concept, art style and especially outstanding soundtrack... I find myself listening to it every once in a while.Highly recommended! Great game for a "quick" run now and then, whereby "quick" can last you up to an hour.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2013
												Extreme bang for your buck here. Basically a roguelike platformer/action game with fiendish difficulty. You can unlock a bunch of different classes that fit your playstyle. While you play you can find tons of passive abilities that make you stronger but don't waste too much time looking for them! The longer you stay in a level the higher the difficulty gets. You have to decide whether you stay fighting a never ending wave of monsters just to get stronger, or defeat the boss as early as you can to get to the next level. There is permadeath but surprisingly enough it never gets frustrating, it is always just the right amount of challenging. You learn more about the game as you play and get better and farther every time. Not to mention the beautiful art and atmosphere. Seriously one of the funnest games I've ever played. Oh yeah and it has freaking co-op for christ's sake. The only problem I have is that sometimes way too many monsters spawn on a small platform and it makes it near impossible to manuever normally while trying to kill them. Buy it, you will not regret it.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Risk of rain is fantastic! The game has a very simple yet detailed pixel art style, and interesting monster, weapon, and character designs, each masterfully animated.The music seems to be inspired by retro game beats, yet feels fresh, and oscillates from being adreniline pumping, to calm and relaxing, it's a good, fun, varied sountrack. The simple yet deep gameplay, offers various characters to unlock, each offering very unique movesets that all have been perfectly balanced, so one should be able to find one character that fits their playstyle. While the game is hard, it never feels so due to monsters having an unfair advantage, however several artifacts can also be unlocked to alter gameplay so it either ends up easier, or more difficult. Additionally three difficulty levels can be selected, so you can cater the challenge to your own tastes.The gist of the game is to fight off a neverending wave of enemies, that become progressively more difficult the longer the game is in play, over the course of 6 levels. Each level is completed by first finding a teleporter, then fighting off against a boss, and surviving a time limit wherein serveral enemies will spawn to attack the player, after successfully doing so the player will be transported to the next level.A lot of work went into the design of the game, from the easy to navigate menu's, to the environments available, and amount of enemies you can come across, to the games ostensibly simple story that reveals more depth as you dig into the lore. Along with the many secrets, hidden areas, and unlockables to discover.Multiplayer is a blast, but unfortunately very difficult to set up with others...Risk of rain is fun on all levels, and an excellent addition to the indie genre, that should keep one entertained for hours!Score: 4.5/5 -0.5 due to the difficulty in setting up a multiplayer game.Sincerely,- Celx RequinWebsite: www.cancer-cinema.comTwitter: www.twitter.com/cancercinemaSteam Game Page:

content:
Posted: November 19, 2013
												Its been a while since I have made a recommendation, and for good reason.  I only make recommendations when I whole heartedly believe the game is not good, but truely spectacular in my mind.  This game encapsulates the rougelike genre and seemlessly moulds it together with a platformer.  It adds its own spice by introducing more powerups to find in your runs as you achieve different feats.  And if you are careful enough, you might spot some of the secrets that hide some of the characters and items.  Its only downfall is the lack of variety in the level set up as it is not truely random.  But the first 25 hours of this game, I have had the time of my life, and I look forward to playing more of it.  Hopefully they expand this game further to have more levels and more level variation and it will be perfect.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Imagine Binding of Isaac as a platformer. That really is what this is.Risk of Rain is a platform game with semi-randomly generated levels, tons of unlockables and a HUGE challenge. You will have to think fast and learn to adapt to the huge onslaught of enemies and deadly bosses that will hunt you through the various environments. The game is fantastic all the way through - I have sunk more than 100 hours into it and I still love it dearly. Worth every penny.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												I'm normally not a fan of these sorts of games as your runs can depend entirely on how lucky you are with drops. Risk of Rain solves this problem by allowing you to pick what loot you get out of each chest. This really turned this game from another rouge-like into a game where you can plan your builds and where strategy matters.Combine that with an excellent astethic, a beautiful soundtrack and online/local co-op and I cannot recommend this game enough, even if you normally aren't a fan of rouge-like action platformers.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												A really good time!  I've obviously put quite a few hours into this game, although the lack of a save+quit feature means that I spent only 50 hours actually playing the game, and the other 40 hours were spent in the pause menu, so I didn't lose progress when I had to stop mid-game.Lots of interesting enemies, abilities, and items.  The difficulty curve is quite steep at first, but once you've died a dozen times or so, you'll have unlocked a few more characters, and some useful items.  The 'story', as told via the Monster Logs you collect from enemies, is straightforward and simplistic, but the world-building/detail about the monsters and their lives is nice.  The item log is also pretty fun, since all the items are cargo, scattered when your ship crashes, and come with little descriptions detailing their sender, recipient, and generally a 'letter' accompanying them.Very much worth the $10, and it seems to go on sale fairly regularly if that's still too much.  Good for filling a spare 20-60 minutes, very replayable.  One issue with the multiplayer is (allegedly, I haven't tried it much/only played local) fairly poorly implemented when it comes to game creation.  No server lists, so you either need to have friends who own it, or organise a game in the steam forum.  The actual multiplayer gameplay is very fun, since you can get some good synergy between characters that you just can't have playing solo.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												SKIP TO THE BOTTOM FOR PROS AND CONS (*TL;DR)This game is one I picked up off my first ever paycheck (for writing) for me and 3 friends. I really only played it with 2 of them, as usually one of their games would crash about halfway through. We had a blast with it anyways. I have 43 hours logged, and about 35 of those are co-op. I've found this game to be a overlooked indie gem, and I like it a lot more than some more mainstream titles.GAMEPLAY:This is where the game really shines, and if you intend on buying this game, this will be the reason why. At the start of the game, you can only choose one class. Once you've chosen your class, you're thrown into a 2D platforming playing field. From there, you have to run, jump, climb, and shoot your way through a foreign planets inhabitants til you find a portal to the next level. Upon reaching the portal, you activate it, and have to fight a boss. This proscess goes on for as long as you want, but you can't fight the final boss til 'Level' 5. However, through gameplay, you can unlock more and more classes. I never felt like one class was more OP than another though, every class is only as OP as your skill level with said class is. This makes it easy to get into a rut with just one class, and play nothing but that class. I personally made it a point to beat the game as a different class almost every playthrough. Playing as multiple classes is incentivized by the fact that every class has a different ending (Resulting in a very minor dialogue change at the end). Multiple playthroughs are incentivized mainly by unlockables, but this falls short when you realize that all you're unlocking is things to help you with more playthroughs. It's kinda like Ouroborous, with the "Logs" being the only collectible that's really worth playing multiple times for.I, however, was determined to squeeze every last drop of fun I could from this game. So I probably beat the damn thing about 10 times (Not exagerating). It's a short game, about an hour and a half to beat on a short run, but it never took more than three hours to beat if we were having good luck. Multiple playthroughs are kept fresh by Artifacts, and  random generation, more on Artifacts later. The random generation doesn't mean that the levels are 100% random. There are about 2 - 4 different area variations per level, (Not counting the last stage) this means predesigned levels. But all the spawn loacations are randomly generated, forcing you to search every inch of the map sometimes. You learn the map layouts very quick this way. But one thing that helps out, are the Artifacts. Sometimes the map layout you get will have a puzzle in it, weather it's an agillity puzzle that requires quick movement, or just figuring out where a special hole is, they all lead to one place: Artifacts. Artifacts are certainly an intresting way to keep the game fresh, with each one augmenting the game in some way. They also all balance out. For example, one of the artifacts I used the most gave you +500% damage output, but you start the game at 10% of what your base health would otherwise be. Since I was pretty skilled, I basically just got a 500% damage amplifier. However, some of these relics do nothing for you til the end, which was pretty dissapointing. Such as making enemies explode on death, but the explosion only damages you. On top of that, the sheer ammount of explosions sometimes would cause my friends games to crash, and I think I had a few crashes because of it as well. The game is prone to fits of crashes every now and then, and it sucks. Especially in co-op where you come to rely on items your friends have that boost you. Another thing: In co-op, there's no way to rejoin a game you have left. There is no drop in/drop  out system, making for a pretty annoying experience when things crash. On top of that, if you die in co-op, there's no way to revive you until the next level. Since you lose all your gold (Which does convert to XP at the end of the level, so thankfully you level up with everyone else) at the end of the level, you wind up helpless for the onslaught that is to come. You're basically baggage if you die one time! There should have been a way to revive friends by spending your money, or to come back from the dead by forfeiting something. It's a tad bit punishing, and while this is a rougelike, this feature just doesn't translate well to co-op.STORY:This is where Logs come in. Occasionally, when you kill a monster, you will get it's Log. A Log is basically a short journal entry written by your character about the creature, accompanied by some nice artwork. The story is nice, I guess. I can't really say too much, because I wasn't compelled enough to go out and farm for all the logs. I've read about half of them, and they were okay I guess. They aren't really a masterpiece but at the same time, it's not♥♥♥♥♥♥ Story isn't the focous here though, so I'm not upset about this in the slightest.GRAPHICS:I personally loved the graphics. It's exactly what it needs to be, and nothing more. Simplistic yet intricate pixel art that perfectly captures the feel the developers were going for. The graphics do exactly what they set out to do, and I like what they set out to do, so therefore I like the graphics of this game.SOUND:As with most roguelike soundtracks, it tends to get repettitive. The songs are very nice, and do fit the mood of this game, they just aren't my cup of tea I guess. After a playthrough or  two, I turned them off and listened to other soundtracks in the background. I turned them back on towards the end though, because I really couldn't find a soundtrack better suited for this game.PROS:-Good solid and enjoyable gameplay-The game stays fresh for quite awhile-The graphics are really nice-Enough collectible to keep the game running on fumes for awhileCONS:-After a few playthroughs, you're artificially padding your experience-The collectibles aren't worth much if you've already beat the game (Besides logs)-Frequent crashing in co-op-Co-op is just very buggy, but still playable-The game gets slightly mundane after awhile (Although that didn't stop me from playing 43 hours)NOTES:-I found a lot of enjoyment in this game, and had a good time with my friends-Story takes a back seat to gameplay[B+] - Worth the buy, I'd say a got a little more than my $9.99 USD for this, and it's well worth that pricetag. You get what you pay for, and a little tiny bit more.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Risk or Rain is an absolutely amazing game to purchase. It's very addictive and interactive. Absolutely worth the $10.00 I paid. It does get a bit hectic though. Hectic to a point that some lower-end computers will get some lag issues (but in my experience, if you farmed a bit, you should have at least a bit of lag by the end level). It does have a bit of issues with multiplayer too. The replay value of this game is absolutely phenomenal. I've replayed the game countless times and it's still very fun to play, both singleplayer and multiplayer. The amount of different scenarios that arise are almost endless. I highly recommend this game to anyone that likes rogue-like games or a game that really grabs your attention. :) :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Ok, so this is going to be a verly decent length review of Risk of Rain, I have about 60 hours in it. and I have beat the game countless times. So, lets begin. As a I will be writing "RoR" as a  anagram for Risk of Rain.Risk of Rain is a sidescrolling 2-D platformer with co-op the sub genre of rogue likes, This means that every playthrough while can seem similer they will be 90% of the time different, also rogue likes are know for their brutal difficuitly RoR is no exeption to this rule though this game has a unquie mechanic there is a timer in the top  right coner as the timer goes up the game gets harder tougher enemies spawn this creates a great risk and reward feeling "Do I stay to get better items/level up or do I leave now with weaker enemies for the next level". With a amazing soundtrack that I can only describe as electronic orchestra and a 8-bit grapics style  that is pretty to look at. Like I said before the game by all means is a platformer though it as a emphasis on combat. The game has eleven playable characters most of which you unlock by a varity of ways, each character has a unique playstyle from the others.  as a example the acrid is a creature that uses acid to attack by either leaving it on the ground or shooting it at enemies  to do a damage over time effects.  Like mention before the game is quite hard on the default difficulty, while fighting your way on a  planet you crash landed on you find items and and dodging and kill the inhabitants of said planet. While you're in any said level you collect gold to buy items at shops that give you effects like for example, the Guardian's Heart it gives a shield that recharges after not taking damage over a period of time, the ukulele which gives a chance to do Area of effect electric damage on your hits. As you move along the 2d map either if its climbing upwards or to just going left to right you need to find the teleporter to move onto the next level, once the teleporter is activated a boss spawns with a timer, the timer counts down till you can teleport to the next level though you can only teleport once the boss is dead, once dead it drops a item, Once time timer hits zero and teleport but it also stops enemies from spawning on that level so you can quickly go buy something and head back if you choose no worrys about dying. The game has 6 levels of said 6 level  there are 11 map themes though the maps are partly randomly generated. Once you beat the fifth level you get a choose, go to the final level or go back to the starting level (though harder bosses and enemies spawn now to keep it intersting) and keep grinding items.  The game has amazing replayability with over 100 items! and being quite challenging this combinded with having co-op as a option in the game just results in a blast! Plus the game is quite cheap with it being eleven dollers flat. It also does a great job of saying "Game maker's engine can make good stuff as well guys!"I love this game, and enjoyed the time spent with it so much.  The game as amazing soundtrack solid gameplay that is satisflying/fun and a ton of replayabiltiy solo or multiplayer you're sure to have a blast. The game earns at least a 9/10.  (Would link steam page but we're here so...) To buy the sound track go here: https://chrischristodoulou.bandcamp.com/album/risk-of-rain (favorite track: Coalescence) Thanks for reading! Hope you could find it useful if you would like to send me any critism by all means post it on my steam profile/here thanks!  If you want to watch me play games I stream over at www.twitch.tv/mrfirestorm
